ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LOWER HDB FLAT PRICES
(Request for)


    1. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will consider lowering its flat prices in line with the fall in prices in the private property market to make it easier for non-owners to own a home and for owners to upgrade to a better flat.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the selling prices of Housing and Development Board flats are not determined by prices of private residential properties. They are based on the costs incurred by the HDB and the subsidy provided by Government. The present sale prices of HDB flats are heavily subsidized and are well below current market prices of comparable private flats. HDB prices are pegged at a level within the means of most Singaporeans who want to own a home or upgrade to a better flat. To lower prices means to increase the subsidy between market prices and the present HDB prices. Selling prices of new HDB flats are well below the market prices of old HDB flats. There is therefore no reason to further lower flat prices.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Would the Minister please tell this House whether the tender prices for the construction of HDB flats have fallen last year?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the subsidy is calculated at the development cost incurred by HDB less the selling price. That is equal to the subsidy. For example, if the development cost of a flat is $60,000 and the selling price is $40,000, the subsidy is $20,000.

HDB ADVERTISEMENTS FOR PROFESSIONALS OVERSEAS


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development why the Housing and Development Board has advertised vacancies for Accountants, Architects, Administrative Officers and Computer Professionals overseas and why it was not possible to recruit persons for these positions amongst Singaporeans.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the overwhelming majority of candidates recruited by the HDB are through local recruitment exercises. Overseas recruitment is resorted to only if the Board encounters difficulties in recruiting suitable candidates locally.

Column: 386



    In 1985, 180 graduates were recruited locally, as compared to only four graduates recruited overseas. However, the local recruitment exercises succeeded only in attracting suitable candidates for the more junior posts, but not for the senior ones. Only eight out of the 180 local graduates recruited have the necessary experience to fill the senior posts, while all the four overseas graduates recruited have five or more years of experience. Suitable Singaporean candidates are either already partners in professional practices or in well established positions and did not want to join the HDB. The vacancy position for the senior posts is further aggravated by the resignation of 20 experienced officers in 1985. The HDB therefore had to advertise overseas for the posts of Accountants, Architects, Administrative Officers and Computer Professionals to attract suitable applicants for these posts at senior management level.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am indebted to the Minister for giving us the whole history of the general practice and policy of the HDB. But does the Minister realize that my question is directed particularly to the advertisement which was reported in December 1985? Perhaps the Minister could confine his answer to this exercise and not give the House the history of HDB policy.

    May this House be told, first of all, whether the salaries offered to these people overseas, these expatriates, were the same as were offered to the locals? Secondly, were they offered housing in addition to their salaries? Thirdly, when were these posts advertised locally? Fourthly, how many of the local architects, accountants and others responded to this advertisement? Fifthly, may we know why they were not found suitable for these vacancies?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would suggest to the Member for Anson to submit a Written Question so that I could give a very detailed Written Answer on all the points he has raised, because they are not part of the Oral Question that he has asked.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I will send you a Written Question.

DEFERMENT OF HDB LOAN REPAYMENT


    3. Mr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development if he will outline the steps which Housing and Development Board home-owners, who are facing difficulties in their housing loan repayment, can take to defer their loan repayment schedules.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB home buyers who are facing difficulties in their housing loan repayment can arrange with the HDB to:

    a) extend the maximum loan repayment period to 25 years;

    b) make partial payment of monthly instalments temporarily and repay the arrears in subsequent instalments if the home buyers are in financial hardship;

    c) include another family member as joint owners of the flat so that his/her CPF contribution can also be used to pay the monthly instalment;

    d) sublet a room to supplement the family income;

    e) defer the instalment payment temporarily if the home buyers have lost their jobs or suffered business failures and the CPF Accounts are depleted.

    The drop in the HDB mortgage rate announced recently will also help to reduce the financial burden on the home buyers.

     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Mr Speaker, Sir, if they have lost their job and are unable to obtain another job, how long would this deferment be allowed?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: HDB will normally allow a deferment of six months initially and this can be further extended. But usually those who lost their jobs are able to find another job within six months. But if they cannot find a suitable job, HDB is prepared to extend beyond six months.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether in the cases of deferment of payments, interest will cease to run or whether interest will also be suspended?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the repayment will be suspended but not the interest.

PULAU LANGKAWI TRAGEDY
(Returning bodies to Singapore)


    4. Encik Wan Hussin bin Hj Zoohri asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs what steps the Government took to facilitate the bringing back of the bodies of the victims of the Pulau Langkawi tragedy to Singapore.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs learned of the Pulau Langkawi tragedy at about 5 pm on 10th February 1986, which was a public holiday in Singapore. The Singapore High Commission in Kuala Lumpur was immediately alerted and the Ministry took action to inform the families of the deceased. The Ministry made arrangements, through the High Commission, to have the bodies flown back on 11th February for burial in Singapore. As there were no scheduled flights available from Pulau Langkawi to Singapore, the High Commission chartered an aircraft on behalf of the families to fly the bodies to Singapore. The bodies arrived at 5.50 pm on 11th February and they were buried on the same day under special arrangements made by the Police and the Ministry of the Environment.

HOTEL IN-HOUSE VIDEO PROGRAMMES
(Advertisements)


    5. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether advertisements are allowed in in-house video programmes provided in hotels.

Column: 389



    The Minister of State for Communications and Informatiom (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Minister for Communications and Information): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    We have allowed hotels to provide in-house video service for the entertainment of their guests. But, like all other video operators, they are not permitted to insert advertisements in the video programmes.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): It appears to be an undue or unnecessary restraint on our business. Why did the Ministry or its officials not respond when a press report on this matter came out?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: They are like all other video operators. And video operators have to comply with a licensing condition - they are not allowed to have advertisements. So even for hotels, the same condition applies.

PREFERENTIAL ADDITIONAL REGISTRATION FEE
(Raising of 10-year limit)


    6. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information if he will raise the 10-year limit on motorcars for Preferential Additional Registration Fee to save foreign exchange.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the PARF scheme was introduced in 1975 as an incentive to encourage car owners to scrap their cars before they are 10 years old. The objective is to reduce the number of old cars so that there would be fewer breakdowns and greater safety on our roads, and also to minimize the traffic congestion during peak hours caused by such breakdowns.

Column: 390



    This policy has proved effective over the last 10 years. We now have a relatively young car population. Raising the 10-year age limit will mean more old vehicles with a greater likelihood of breakdowns returning to our roads. That will result in greater inconvenience for all road users.

    The PARF scheme has been an incentive to encourage scrapping before the cars become unroadworthy and have to be scrapped out of necessity. There is no compulsion. Car owners are free to choose when to scrap their cars. Those who have well-maintained cars can keep them beyond the 10-year limit. It is unnecessary to give an incentive to owners who have cars older than 10 years old and wish to scrap them when they are no longer roadworthy.

    I should add, Sir, that our car restraint policies, in fact, achieve what the hon. Member appears to ask for, ie, to save on foreign exchange. By keeping the car population at a low level, we have reduced the amount of foreign exchange spent on the purchase of new cars.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, does the Minister not agree that the compulsory inspection of vehicles contributes to a reduction in breakdowns of vehicles?

     Some hon. Members: Hear, hear.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the compulsory inspection ensures that minimum standards are kept. But we all know that old equipment and old machinery do have a greater tendency to break down with increasing age. So too with cars.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, we do not keep a record of all the cars that break down on the roads. But I am sure the Member for Whampoa will remember that way back in the 70s it was a common sight to see cars breakdown along the roadside and owners plucking off a branch from a tree and sticking it at the back of the bumpers.

     Some hon. Members: They still do.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, it is probable that the recession was the primary cause for the slower growth of cars over the last 12 months. The PARF is a different scheme altogether. The PARF is meant to keep the number of old cars down to a reasonable number.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the Ministry does not keep track of where all the old cars go. But we know that most of the old cars have been scrapped locally. If the Member is interested, Sir, I could inform the House that in 1975, one car out of every five was 10 years or older. Today, one car out of 14 is 10 years or older. That has helped significantly in ensuring that we do not have serious traffic congestions, particularly during peak hours.

BAN ON RELIGIOUS MUSIC DURING THAIPUSAM


    7. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs why the police forbid the playing of religious music and singing of religious songs at temples and by those accompanying the persons carrying kavadi along the route during the observance of Thaipusam.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Police did not forbid the playing of religious music and singing of religious songs at the temples during Thaipusam. Religious music was played and religious songs were sung at the temples. Also, the singing of religious Kavadi songs and hymns by those accompanying the Kavadi carriers was not prohibited.

Column: 392



    Sir, the Police have disallowed the playing of music to accompany all religious processions on public roads since 1973. The experience of the Police was that the playing of music en route slowed down the pace of the procession and caused serious traffic congestion. Moreover, there have been complaints by devotees that some persons accompanying Kavadi carriers were making a mockery of this solemn religious occasion by playing bonggos, cymbals, drums and even dustbin covers, plastic pails and metal containers.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, I have heard of complaints from some devotees that there was a certain political party who sent its members ---

     Mr Speaker: Please let me have your supplementary question, Dr Koh?

     Dr Koh Lam Son: I will come to that quickly, Sir.

The Member for Telok Blangah asked me what is my view of this. Well, it is certainly both irresponsible and despicable because it shows scant regard for what is a solemn religious occasion. It also has the potential for mischief, misunderstanding and disorder when a political party distributes or sells political broadsheets and pamphlets during a solemn religious occasion in a public place.

ACCIDENT AND EMERGENCY TREATMENT
(Payment of fees)


    8. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Health (a) whether the Accident and Emergency department of the hospitals turn away persons if they do not happen to have on them the fee payable for the treatment; and (b) whether the same fee is again levied for repeat attendance at the department for follow-up treatment.

     The Minister of State for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will answer on behalf of my Minister.

Column: 397



    Persons requiring emergency treatment are not turned away at the Accident and Emergency Department of Government hospitals if they do not happen to have the fee payable for the treatment. They are given medical attention as soon as possible and a bill is presented to the patient for settlement at a later date.

    The Accident and Emergency Departments do not, as a rule, undertake follow-up treatment. Patients requiring follow-up treatment are referred to the Specialist Outpatient Clinics or the Primary Health Care Clinics for attention. However, should the patient return within 12 hours because of a recurrence or persistence of his symptoms, he will not be charged for the repeat attendance.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, supplementary questions for the Minister of State. First of all, he says in emergency cases people who do not have the money are not turned away. Would he say what are these emergency cases where they are not turned away? Will he then concede that there were several cases of people turned away because they did not have the $12 on them? And does this also extend to people coming in with cuts or wounds on their bodies?

    Secondly, about the repeat attendance, would he confirm that a similar fee of $12 is again levied for dressings on surgical wounds when they are asked to come back again the next day or the day after, simply for the wound to be dressed?
